posts.name: Adrian
posts.cooked:
Ahead of the FIRST Championship, 3005 is pleased to release the CAD for our 2024 robot Surge!

Top-level robot: Onshape

Block CAD: Onshape

Yet again, another public CAD release!!! This year, we are sharing both robot and block CAD to showcase how block CAD is used in respective subsystems. Anyone going to champs, feel free to stop by and take a look or ask questions!

Some quick notes: The CAD has not been cleaned up, and the model shows the robot in its current working state. Also, any references to the block CAD in the top-level robot can not be right-clicked and opened to the linked document.
Just enough time for @waialua359 to machine a new bot for this week!

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
Id like to hear your opinion on the NEO Vortexes.  We opted to lean towards Krakens for drive and the regular NEO stock we ordered for the season this year instead of buying into the vortex.

How have they (and particularly the replaceable shaft) held up through the rigor of the season? any need to replace or things of note for their uses?

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked:
I am not 3005, but we also used the new Neo Vortex motor on most systems in the robot.

The motors on the shooter were pretty good, I don‚Äôt remember them causing any problems, only a couple can issues.

But when it comes to our mk4i swerve, OHH BOY Especially the Spark flex, but also the motor itself, caused sooo many problems. I also have seen a post about it, talking about the problems Vortex did on a mk4i.

So, overall the motor is nice, we will definitley use it for prototypes and maybee some parts of our robot next year, but for right now I would not recommend putting those on a mk4i swerve. But, I will add, that after using it this season, we have seen how unstable it can be (breaking, burning etc‚Ä¶)

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked:
I can‚Äôt really offer an opinion that means anything because I‚Äôm biased but I can talk about how they were during the season.

Generally we‚Äôve had a very positive experience with them this season.

Mechanically we‚Äôve had no issues.  The set that‚Äôs on the drivetrain has been through two competitions plus tons of practice.  SOP for 3005 is to remove swerve modules after they‚Äôve been run for a while and use them as spares so they are ‚Äúknown good‚Äù.  We did the same for the launcher although that change was for upgrades.

The feeder motor hasn‚Äôt been removed ever.  The intake has been upgraded a bunch of times so I can‚Äôt tell you how long that motor has been on there but it‚Äôs been shuffled between comp robot, practice robot, and spare intake so it has plenty of mileage.

We had several of the software bugs that other teams had in the early versions of the firmware but those were fixed by the software updates pretty early on.

Anecdotally SPARK Flex has been a major step up in reliability for us.  Generally we make a couple swerve module swaps or replace motors and controllers throughout the season but that hasn‚Äôt been the case this year.  The lower number of electrical connections helps.

posts.name: Adrian
posts.cooked:
Thank you! : )

The longer part prevents notes from getting stuck on the climber, and the u-shaped part holds the surgical tubing we use to counterbalance the launcher!

posts.name: Ryan Moore
posts.cooked:
Why did y‚Äôall use four Vortex motors on your shooter? I this for an increase in accuracy or a decrease in spin up time??

posts.name: Charlie
posts.cooked: Seeing how much you guys used it on your robot, do you plan on sharing more about your use of Self-Reinforced Polypropylene this season?

posts.name: Adrian
posts.cooked:
We used four vortex motors mainly because of their mechanical simplicity. Using four vortexes means no mechanical linkage between the four corners of the launcher, and we are also able to induce spin on the notes by creating a difference between the two sides of the launcher, though this could be done without four motors.

We have an army of Ender 3 pros using Octoprint to connect to them individually. Some even have cameras for timelapses!

posts.name: Adrian
posts.cooked: Yes, we are planning on sharing more!

posts.name: Tomer Danielli
posts.cooked: On your behind the bumpers you guys mentioned you use Sub Reinforced polypropylene. Could you share where you buy it from?

posts.name: Max Conine
posts.cooked: How was the programming for these vortex motors on your shooter? Were they easy to pid tune? How accurate could you target a range of rpm‚Äôs or did you always use a fixed rpm while shooting? We had some difficulty pid tuning the vortexes on our shooter but I wonder if it was because we had such a low moment of inertia shooter.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked:
Velocity control on the shooter vortex worked just fine. We were able to get the velocity within about 1% of the setpoint for all four motors. The max vortex RPM was ~5100 and min ~1900. A few points I can think of off hand that helped:

Setting the encoder average depth and sample delta allows faster response and higher gains. Its a tradeoff of smoother signal and quantization error. We ended up with average depth of 8 and sample delta of 32ms.

Setting the encoder average depth and sample delta allows faster response and higher gains. Its a tradeoff of smoother signal and quantization error. We ended up with average depth of 8 and sample delta of 32ms.

The updates to sysid were great this year and got us most of the way. Combined with URCL, its really easy to write a quick routine to run all of the sysid code. There was still some manual tuning required, though I believe partially due to the next point.

The updates to sysid were great this year and got us most of the way. Combined with URCL, its really easy to write a quick routine to run all of the sysid code. There was still some manual tuning required, though I believe partially due to the next point.

The PID controller on the Flex should have the output limit after the feedforward in this diagram . The problem here is, we don‚Äôt want the motors to apply voltage in the opposite direction, but we do want it to correct the feedforward (e.g. negative error gain added to the positive arbFF). However this isn‚Äôt possible since it is clamped at 0 before the arbFF. To work around this, the kV and kS were lowered slightly so the controller only corrects ‚Äòup‚Äô. The other option would be to set the min output range to some value that, after the arbFF, would still never end up negative. This point is a bit nit picky, and performance without this point would have been totally fine. It‚Äôs just nice to eliminate one variable when trying to evaluate overall system accuracy.

The PID controller on the Flex should have the output limit after the feedforward in this diagram . The problem here is, we don‚Äôt want the motors to apply voltage in the opposite direction, but we do want it to correct the feedforward (e.g. negative error gain added to the positive arbFF). However this isn‚Äôt possible since it is clamped at 0 before the arbFF. To work around this, the kV and kS were lowered slightly so the controller only corrects ‚Äòup‚Äô. The other option would be to set the min output range to some value that, after the arbFF, would still never end up negative. This point is a bit nit picky, and performance without this point would have been totally fine. It‚Äôs just nice to eliminate one variable when trying to evaluate overall system accuracy.

Being able to tune P I D kV kS while the system is running makes things much quicker and easier.

Being able to tune P I D kV kS while the system is running makes things much quicker and easier.

Thanks!
